description.text:
This is a spool roller that attaches to a Lulzbot power supply.
http://www.lulzbot.com/en/71-12vdc-20a-240w-power-supply.html
It's working well and easily adjustable for different sized spools. Should also work to hold two spools for a dual extruder setup.

Print the STL two times and assemble with 8mm threaded rod 120mm or greater.
I used the stock prusa z leadscrews(210mm)that are wide enough for two spools. Use 4 608 bearing. The ribs attach to the power supply with 6 M4x10mm screws. You can modify the SCAD file to fit different dimensions or to print better on your machine. The scad does depend on MCAD.
https://github.com/elmom/MCAD/zipball/master

We designed a motorized stirrer for high school chemistry classes. This is meant to be used for larger beakers to mix large volume solutions in a timely manner. Please note that the motor, switch, battery, wiring and glass stirring rods are not included - this is only the body, covers, and the connectors.

As high school chemistry students, we were not allowed to use any of the expensive machinery to aid us in mixing solutions for certain labs. As a result we found that it was tedious to fully mix certain chemicals together in a timely manner. To solve this we designed a motorized chemical stirrer for larger beakers. Some of the things we had to keep in mind while designing the piece were the sizes of beakers and stirring rods, as well as the amount of time we had to make the pieces.

title: ROBO3D fan mount mod for E3D V5 hotend nozzle

description.text:
NEW:
Side mount allows warm air to blow to the side so that cooling fan does not pick up warm air thus making cooling more efficient. This fan mount bracket is redesigned to work with E3D hotend.
E3D Hotend takes more space then standard ROBO3D nozzle so original fan bracket had to be removed and replaced at the front with this one.
Installation:

description.header: 1 If you haven't done so already, turn your E3D blower fan toward the back, so it draws air from the back (Look at my picture to see)

description.text:
Printing:
Print on hair gel or spray (for eazy removal)
Print 100% solid.
0.3 layer height is good.
Due to small size model, cooling while printing is required so keep your fan pointed at the model while it prints, or print at slower speed and make sure you have some cold piece of metal to press on a model edges if it starts to curl up (PLA). Smooth cold metal handle of your favorite spoon will do the job :)
No support print required.

title: Z-Axis Stepper Bracket for TEVO Tarantula

description.text:
A sturdy and rigid z-rod bracket for right (and optional left) mounting for TEVO Tarantula.

I wasn't happy with the other z-brackets on thingiverse, so designed this upgraded one to satisfy my requirements:

  • Dual cross support for added rigidity.
  • Back plate for added rigidity.
  • Elongated screw holes for stepper motor, can actually adjust the Y offset!
  • Low profile, so you can make the most of your Z space.
  • Has both right and left side brackets.

I would recommend ABS, I have had PLA Z brackets warp over time, especially with ambient heat.

remixed_from.author: nigeljohnson73
remixed_from.title: B+ Pi Cam Ultimaker 2 timelapse harness

title: Mic Stand Raspberry Pi Holder - Vertical
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
nigeljohnson73 made a great timelapse harness, but it only worked with the Raspberry Pi Camera Module version 1, so I made a version that worked with the RPi Camera Module v2.1

Then, I decided that I wanted to try and secure his timelapse harness to something. I have a few mic stands kicking around, so I made an adapter that converts the mic stand (5/8"-27) to the harness (M16x2.0 metric).

This is borderline remix territory, and it works well with the timelapse harness, so I'll call it a remix, but I've basically created a vertical Raspberry Pi holder that connects to the standard mic stand. As you can see by the pictures, this is a complete set from holding the camera steady at the appropriate angle, to cable management, all the way down to holding the RPi closer to the camera. I went out and bought a 24" ribbon cable, but I imagine with this set-up, you could have one even shorter!

Because the keyholes are strangely off-center on the back of my (wonderful!) RPi case, securing the case to vertically causes it to lean to one side. I think the next iteration will be a horizontally-oriented back-plate. For those who are running their RPi caseless, don't forget to see the cage nigeljohnson73 made!

(Here's the case I use, by the way...don't forget to tell them I sent you, even though I won't get anything - it's just nice to know I'm sending business their way. It's a cool company!)

https://www.amazon.com/Zebra-Virtue-Black-Raspberry-C4Labs/dp/B01F1O0Q8U

Also, as with any of my ideas/designs, please let me know if you'd like an alternate version. I can't always say I'm going to have the time, but it's good to have the ideas out there!

I can't wait to print a Baby Groot planter!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Glass bed with PVA glue, and a rock-solid leveling is the best way to print. The stronger springs that came with my glass bed make it so much easier to keep things level, even after multiple prints and multiple days!

Been printing with PLA more, recently, due to the reduced odor, toxicity, and lower temperatures. Seems more forgiving?

Fusion 360

My fourth remix using reverse engineering, rather than the original STL file. I basically just tweaked the "back-plate" so that it runs the entire length symmetrically, adjusted the size, added six symmetrical holes on the back (for zip strips or twist ties or whatever your thing is), plus one additional hole in the base for pass-through. Added the same fillets for consistency, plus who doesn't like roundness?

Thanks again to nigeljohnson73 for the exceptional timelapse harness design!

title: Anet A8 double power supply cover

description.text:
I liked the original design quite much. However, in order to finalize this upgrade:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2220401
I wanted to have the following:
-A second power supply, because the original one seemed a bit whacky to add more load
-Power to both supplies should be switched with only one switch
-No mains cables running around the frame

By placing a small 5V2A LED power supply next to the original one, I solved all three things. For that I enlarged the original case (now it stands flat on the surface). The original flaw of the lack of a mount on the left side remains, so I just used this design
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2087889
and fixed it with two 3mm self-threading screws.

Design was quick and dirty so expect some (or more) imprecision.

0.2mm in PLA witha .4mm nozzle did work quite well on this one.

author: BourrinDesBois

description.text:
Our goal was to create simple, helpful, and effective model displaying the five main stages of Mitosis for both biology teachers and classes; effectively displaying the intricate steps as well as being colorful and easy to break down.
Previously, when teaching this section, biology teachers relied heavily on online depictions of the stages and YouTube videos. We wanted to create a physical representation of Mitosis that students could interact with and more easily comprehend.

Requirements Planning After reviewing the brief and generating some ideas for both chemistry and Biology, we decided to go with our idea on a Mitosis model that will show the phases of mitosis for more visual learners. We incorporated the components that will allow teachers to use the model to further explain the steps of mitosis and further help students understand Mitosis. The understanding of mitosis is important for many different units, so the better a student understands it, the better they will do as the progress within biology. Constraints Printing plate size - 17x23 We had to make sure the parts were all big enough to show definition yet not too big We had to fit 6 single chromosomes into each plate, while also having room for centrioles and spindle fibers or nuclei.

Textbook stages of Mitosis Textbook stages of Mitosis (cont.) Lesson Plan Our lesson plan was to work with a science teacher in our school and develop a tool or model to make teaching easier. The model was developed alongside the teacher as to further the use they will get out of it. In our case, we modeled mitosis off of our Biology textbooks model. We used solid works education edition to design a easily explained model of mitosis.

title: Herringbone gear rack and pinion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a herringbone (a version of the double helical) gear rack and pinion, remixed from a single helical rack and pinion by janssen86. The doubling up of the helical teeth removes the axial thrust of a single helical gear and also helps keep the gear centered.

I printed a test print prior to using this as a component of a bigger project, but found that both I and my kids also enjoyed this as a fidget toy! There is something quite satisfying about how nicely the pinion stays on track on the gear.

No supports needed. I printed at 0.20mm resolution with a 0.40mm nozzle. Note that in the current version (not the one I printed) the pinion prints upside-down relative to the rack. This is deliberate, as the bottom side gets squashed a little, and this should symmetrize the squashing. The squashing made my test print not align so nicely. I should do another test print at some point.

comments.text: i keep getting an error trying to export this out of the customizer... any idea why?
comments.author: injoi

comments.text:
This is not a double helical gear. It is a herringbone gear.
See this:
http://www.tandwiel.info/wp-content/uploads/dubbele-schroefvertanding.jpg
Also the slant of the teeth are commonly different between double helical and herringbone.
comments.author: Wolfie

comments.text: Thanks for pointing this out. Doing a Google Books and a Google Web search, it looks like there are three ways different sources use the terminology:
comments.author: Wolfie

comments.text: It will also assist others here in searching.  As most of our extruders (wades for example) use a herringbone gear, that is the term that most people would search for to locate similar objects.  I have found that thingiverse is less likely to produce a search result if the search term does not appear in the keywords, title and description.  In the end I think the name change will facilitate thingiverse's quirky search for people who are looking for herringbone type gears for projects.
comments.author: arpruss

comments.text: And thanks for the comment. I really know very little about gears, but wanted to use this one for a rack and pinion telescope focuser that I'm designing.

description.text:
Made a tape holder with the aim of mounting it to the Ikea "Lack" table. It can be used together with every table, or even as a wall mount.

It is made rolls with a maximum width of approx. 52mm. The "bow" fits perfect for a roll with a Diameter of 75mm (or bigger). The minimum (!) diameter of the roll you can use with this holder is 61mm to press the roll onto it (without using the bow).

author: faustingirault

description.text: This is a very cool center finder invented by http://www.thingiverse.com/hlyman. I rank this as one of the most interesting and useful things on the thingiverse. Certainly the backstory is the most compelling. I scaled it to 75% to fit the replicator bed. I also redesigned the pins to make them a press fit, thus eliminating the need for screws on those parts. I also redesigned the rotating brackets and control knobs to improve their operation after scaling. I put multiple parts in one file to speed up printing. NOTE: Scale the Right Arm file using inches->mm button or download the last file on the list which has the scale fixed already.

Print each set of parts and assemble according to the final picture. The pins are press fit into the donut looking part. The ribbed nature of 3D extrusion parts makes these parts quite hard to get apart. This allows them to act as a screwless fastner. Make sure the mating surfaces of the base and "right" arms are smooth so the mechanism can slide easily under rubber band power. Press control knobs thru the long sides of 4 Arm base so that tab presses into the slots on the "right arm" jaw. Note the right arm jaws are oriented with one of them with its flat back against the flat back of the 4 Arm base. Then the other "right" arm jaw goes on last with the protrusion facing the back of the 4 arm base. The rotating brackets are fastened with #3-1/4" slotted flat head wood screw - http://www.boltdepot.com/Product-Details.aspx?product=7774. Make sure screw will thread without cracking plastic. Don't tighten too much as brackets need to rotate. I set the bed temp to 110C to prevent parts from lifting and warping. I will be adding more details over the next few weeks.

title: FPV Camera Mount - Fat Shark style CCDs for  MultiRotor H Body Modular System - with OpenSCAD Source

description.text: A simple, secure, robust, sturdy and customizable mount for a FatShark 600TVL FPV Tuned CMOS CCD FPV Camera for my MultiRotor H Body Modular System, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:190912 Mount has slight degree of down deflection for the CCD, in which you can easily reduce downward angle by use of simple hobby file. Future revisions, code will allow easier adjustment This mount is used for the 15.5mm square tube designs, however is fully customizable via the OpenSCAD source, so you can easily adjust and modify to your specific needs. Added Helper disk and slide in camera retainer. The slide in camera retainer, is offset by 1mm to allow for variances in the TVL600 CCD housings.

Recommend 2 shells, 20% infill for this at .2 layer height.  
No supports are needed.  
Print time:  ~35 mins.  
Single STL file will print the mount, the slid in retainer and helper disk, which is easily snaps off for clean lines.

description.text:
This made is based on the tutorial from Dave White in Hackaday webpage:

https://hackaday.io/post/44045

I thought it would need some more details so thats the reason of this post. I had some troubles finding the heatbed mentioned in that tutorial, below you can find the link to it:

http://www.ebay.com/itm/4-5-X-6-Heatbed-PCB-Heated-Bed-for-3D-Printing-/261195426302?hash=item3cd075e9fe:g:I8cAAOxyW9RRXFdh

Please check that I only found it with the seller 3dheatbeds. Great HW what they have if you ask me.

The next thing is to find a 3d printer heatbed module (Feel free to do it by yourself if you have some electronics background), the one I used was the most common kind and sell from Amazon:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MY50JL3/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The remaining is the same as Dave's tutorial.

IMPORTANT!!!!! Doing this hack will increase the height of your heatbed the enough to not allow you to print with it.... Print a heatbed spacer for the MPSM before you add the new heatbed! (You can see one of my pictures where I needed to add a contact ribbon to print the spacer haha.

Good luck!

title: Y Carriage Bearing Mounts for Folger Tech 2020 i3

description.text:
TL;DR - Bearing mounts for the FolgerTech 2020 i3 that can hold 1x LM8UU, 1x LM8LUU, or 2x LM8UU. No zip-ties.

I was wanting to learn Fusion 360 and upgrade my printer (FolgerTech 2020 i3) so I started with the bearing mounts on the y carriage. It used the common configuration of one bearing on one rail and two on the other. This is a forgiving arrangement, but can introduce a bit of slop from the play in the single bearing. If you have good rods and make sure they're aligned properly then extending the single bearing can make the bed a little more solid. I also never really liked the idea of using zip-ties to assemble a precision machine, so I designed these to hold the bearings without the need for zip-ties.

Dimensional info:

28mm between bolt hole centers
18.5mm from bottom of carriage plate to bearing center
Designed for 12mm M3 bolts and nuts (assuming 2.5mm plate thickness)
Includes hexagonal recesses to hold the nuts.

I tested the temperature on the underside of my carriage plate and found that at bed temps required for ABS the underside temperature would approach the limits of PLA, but were well within the limits of PETG, which is what I used for my final versions. Note that I have insulation between my heated bed and carriage plate though, so you may want to test for your setup or just play it safe and use ABS.

Folger Tech i3 2020

title: Cl-260 XY-Carrier for LM8UU & 6mm Rods (increases printvolume and makes the printhead fully compatible to Ulitmaker 2)

description.text:
Adds roughly 15mm in height to the Z-Axis und around 5-10mm to X+Y.
A second upgrade which adds another 15mm in Z and another additional 5mm in XüY each might follow soon.
Was only uploaded on special request. Feel free to improve it! :)

Although it's designed for 10mm GT2 belts it should also work very fine with the standard 6mm GT2 belt. You might to cut off the teeth of the belt on one end with a sharp knife to get it fixed easily (looks closely at the pics!)

What it does: New carriers will hold the rods ON the XY-Carriers instead of between them. That gains about ~5mm in EACH XY-Direction plus about 15mm in height.

What you need (BOM):

  • 4x LM8UU or any interchangeable linear bearing (Igus Drylin etc.)
    I recommend to buy high quality LM8UU or if using Drylin use RJUI-01-08, not crappy RJ-Series

  • 2x LM6LUU for new printhead - high Quality of course. Like with LM8UU If you're buying from a unknown source, better buy 4-6x of them and choose the best two

  • 2x 350mm 6mm H6 high precision hardened steel linear rods (stainless if possible) (this length is for the MAX version of the printer)

  • You need to print one of the many Ultimaker 1 or Ultimaker 2 compatible printheads for your Hotend here are tons on Thingiverse, select one you like an print it! Smallest one I know is this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:159987 (I'm currently working on an own printhead for V6 which allows to use maximal printspace, will release soon) T

  • 8 short M3 screws or hotglue to fix the belts

Recommend settings: 0.4mm Nozzle, <=0.3mm Layer Height (optimized for 0.15mm but tested to be working with 0.3mm aswell)

This pen holder is designed to hold onto the Platinum Preppy fountain pens and keep them attached to your Moleskine cover (others may fit, but they are the only ones tested). description.text:
*very small parts, recommended for ages 4+ only!

These have to be printed at .1 layer height for their details to be seen. Even at that, the tiny little critters are a fast print!

If you like them, but don't want to fiddle with a bunch of filament changes, we've made them available on this etsy shop: https://www.etsy.com/shop/LibraryMoose

The Monkey House has a "secret" passageway in the top of the tree that only the monkey can fit down. The bear has to "crawl" into its house. The mouse can lay down or sit in the flower atop its house.

We designed these for a sick little girl relative who received a Calico Critter's set while in the hospital... I mean, Calico Critters need tiny critters to play with too, don't they?! :-)

author: Inubana

print_settings.Notes:: Pretty much any settings should work, but the finer your nozzle, the finer your text details will be. And layer depth will matter if you're switching colors. But pretty much anything should work for basic tags.

description.text:
If you customize this and don't uncheck the checkbox in Customizer saying to publish your new version, everyone on Thingiverse can see your personal information! I have NO control over this!

This customizer script generates luggage / bag tags, with various options for size, lips, text style, position, etc...

The settings should be fairly self-explanatory -- if not, please let me know and I'll improve the help text.

Tag Width/Height is the size of the resulting tag in millimeters. Tag Depth is how thick the base size you want the tag to be.

Corner Radius is just that -- the radius of the corners of the tag.

Typeface is the typeface to use for the text on the tag. The list contains all the current typefaces on fonts.google.com. Any of them should work, but, especially at smaller sizes, some typefaces may result in letters too thin for your printer. You'll need to create and slice to see, but I've found a lot of them at smaller sizes won't print with a .4mm nozzle.

The Tag Hole Position determines if there's a hole in the "inside" of the tag for a strap, or if it adds a "tongue" off the side for the hole.

The lip settings control the presence of, and size of, a raised lip on the top of the tag, creating a border.

You can choose the horizontal alignment (left/right) of the text on the tag.

You can choose to inset or raise the lettering into or above the surface of the tag.

Text Padding determines how much padding between the text and the edge of the tag or the lip of the tag.

Line spacing is the distance (in mm) between lines of text.

After those are set, there are up to four lines of text you can include. To leave a line out, set its size to zero and things will adjust accordingly. However, you can't leave a gap -- if you have a line set to zero, none of the following lines will be included. So if you want three lines, set the forth to zero, if you want two, set three and four and so forth.

In each line, you can set the text, the size (in mm), and how "deep" you want the lettering, in millimeters. This is how raised or lowered the text is depending on if you are raising or embossing the text with the setting above. The "Style" box allows you to pick alternate forms of the typeface you specified, if available (see fonts.google.com to determine if there are other styles available). For example, "Bold", or "Bold Oblique", etc...

The depth settings for the lip, and each of the lines are separate, so you can use slicer capabilities (or tools like Prusa3d's Color Print utility) to change filament at different layers. In the sample image, the black was switched for green just as the first line was rendering, and the rest of the text was a layer higher, so it ended up a dark green. Another color change was set just above the top surface, so the lip could be turned black again.

Using various combinations of inset or raised levels for each component, multiple colors can be included on the tag.

This is a work-in-progress, so comments and feedback is appreciated!

Note, if you use the Customizer app to create your own version of this, make sure you don't mark it to publish if its got personal info on it!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

Pretty much any settings should work, but the finer your nozzle, the finer your text details will be. And layer depth will matter if you're switching colors. But pretty much anything should work for basic tags.

comments.text: Interesting, I didn't think OpenSCAD had a way to get text geometry. (In fact, I did quite a bit of digging, and there's been a lot of complaints about it.)
comments.author: clintec

comments.text: You are correct, it's based on approximations for various text, and it's currently EXTREMELY UGLY.... which is why I don't want to share it until I get the script cleaned up.  There are known ratios for text h/w based on font and character... and after taking size into the mix it get ugly (very quickly).
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: Yeah, that's why I left it out -- for one-off, its pretty easy to just hand-tweak things. If I was going to do a bulk-renderer, I'd probably write a utility to generate the SCAD settings directly, using metrics retrieved from the associated Google (or other) font using a more robust programming environment. The problem is, even if you used some sort of "average" text like a lorem ipsum paragraph, and pre-calculated the average ratios for a given typeface, its still not going to match unless the actual text exactly matches the average letter distributions you calculated them with.
comments.author: clintec

comments.text:
Nice Tool! and timely too. I will need a tag like this in a few weeks.
I see that SCAD has what appears to be a list of local fonts. Is it possible to use one of them instead of the online fonts?

comments.author: DougInAZ

comments.text: I've tried several san serif fonts, and I keep running into the situation where the slicer is unable to outline each letter without running into the one next to it, because the letters are just too tightly spaced.  And, I'm setting the slicer for a 0.3 mm nozzle.  Any suggestions for a font that has a bit more air in it? I have not tried any local fonts, because I haven't tried to figure out how they are enabled yet.
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: I've printed a few tags with "Montserrat Alternates" at 4.5mm at the smallest, and those have all printed flawlessly. (The '@' sign in an e-mail and i and l being too close are where I tend to see issues with fonts, so [email protected] tends to be a problem.) That's with a .4mm nozzle, so you probably could go a little smaller with it.
comments.author: DougInAZ

comments.text: I was using large font sizes, inset text, and all CAPS with the hope that would help.  I'll take another look.  What I have is certainly usable.  I can't imagine anyone not being able to recognize the word CITY, even if the I, T & Y run together.  After all, it's only a luggage tag, and I am likely to be the only one looking for it :-)  I have made tags in Sketchup (CAD) and found that Arial Rounded MT Bold is about a perfect font for 3D printing.  Thanks again for a nice gadget.

remixed_from.title: B-Struder - Bowden extruder with 40Tgear + U604ZZ bearing for 1.75 filament

title: B-Struder - Bowden extruder with MK7 gear + 623ZZ bearing for 1.75mm filament

description.text:
This Remix is to use a MK7 gear + 623zz bearing.

Beware that the motor spindle needs to be long enough if you want it to support the MR105ZZ bearing, I estimate that it needs to be at least some 20mm long, or more.
By 3D calculations and measuring, I estimate that on my motor (Wantai 42BYGHW811L20P1-X3 2.5A 1.8ºstep) this version would not fit as nice as the 40T design, because of the taller gear that puts the MR105ZZ bearing almost popping out off the motor axle. The bearing holder now has a lip to better secure the bearing.

I didn't test this, since I don't really have this gear.
I made this MK7 version for users who have this gear.

The main issue I noticed in the design is that the MK7 gear is longer that the 40T gear I use, so it occupies more of the available motor spindle height, leaving a shorter space to fit the top MR105ZZ support bearing.

If you try this, please give some feedback if it works properly.

Please see the source file for assembly instructions and pictures.

The differences for this one are 2 different printed parts, the arm and the motor mount, to adjust to the bigger MK7 gear and smaller 623ZZ bearing.

The MR105ZZ support and side locking lever are the same (as in the source design for the 40T gear), they just need to be fitted with an extra 2x M3 large washers, between them and the motor mount (pictured in red), to compensate for the taller MK7 gear.

BOM

Besides the plastic for the printed parts, these are the parts used, most are easily found in ebay:

1x bearing MR105ZZ (5 x 10 x 4mm)
1x extruder spring, 7.5mm width, 20mm long, with 1.3mm wire (ebay, just search for "extruder spring")
2x M3 large flat washers, 9mm outer diameter
1x M3 nylon locking nut (for spring tensioner)
1x M3 8mm stainless steel round head phillips screw (to motor mount, under the lever)
1x M3 12mm (or longer) stainless steel round head phillips screw (for spring tensioner)
3x M3 25mm stainless steel round head phillips screw
1x M4 12mm stainless steel round head phillips screw (for the U604ZZ bearing)
1 or 2x PC4-M6 PTFE fitting (M6 screw, for 4mm PTFE tube, 2mm inner hole)
1x Nema 17 Stepper Motor

To use a MK7gear+623zz arm:
1x MK7 toothed gear for 1.75mm filament (13mm height, 12mm width), like this example http://www.ebay.com/itm/MK7-Stainless-Steel-Extruder-Drive-Gear-Hobbed-Gear-For-Reprap-3D-Printer-/251618046413
3x bearing 623ZZ (3 x 10 x 4mm)
2 M3 stainless steel large washers

author: FourOfFour

description.text:
This is a flat representation of the Philadelphia Flyers NHL hockey team logo. This is my first model, and I wanted to test my dual-extruders.
The proper logo is actually three colors, but I left the orange part out, so there is a nifty hole in the middle. I learned some things doing this:
  • the white border is too narrow, so the extruder didn't 'fill' between its sides.
  • my platform must not be level, because the left extruder scraped the surface of the model when the right extruder was working
  • I'd probably flip the whole model so that the shiny finish that comes from the platform would end up on the front of the model

The scad file has a 'z' value that can be adjusted for thickness.  It can generate both the white part and the black part, just comment and uncomment the appropriate module calls at the bottom of the file.
The two stl files can be merged for use with dual-extruder heads. They are labelled for the color they should be rendered in.

description.text:
Haven't got a flagship phone and feel you're missing out on all the VR fun? Attach your GoogleCardboard Viewer to your tablet. The Hudl2 has a cross section 130mm x 10mm but just use the OpenScad file to make the brackets fit your tablet. Mirror the bracket if you want one on both sides.

Default viewer:
https://vr.google.com/intl/en_uk/cardboard/get-cardboard/

Get you going App from Google:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.samples.apps.cardboarddemo

end_space = 3

Just some bins to fit inside this organization case to give me more bins for smaller parts as well as keep washers from sliding underneath the original separators. Plus it is nice to grab the bin you need instead of the entire case when you need a lot of one thing.

One cell means it is one bin per divider area.
Two cell means it is two bins per divider area.
Four cell means it is four bins per divider area.

Organization Case:
http://www.harborfreight.com/24-divider-storage-container-94458.html
or

title: Toyota Prius G3 Wheel Center Cap - KING
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is designed to fit the stock alloy wheel of the third generation (previous generation, at this writing) of the Toyota Prius. The car comes with ugly "pizza cutter" wheel covers that obscure the very nice alloys underneath. But when you take off the stock cover, you are left with a gaping, unfinished hole in the wheel. You can buy a silver plastic hub cap from your Toyota dealer, OR !! you can get a set printed at Shapeways.com for the SAME PRICE !!

Prime, paint and topcoat for best longevity of finish.

NOT designed for FDM printing.

If you want a custom design, contact me.
